s.text: >On Friday 4/19, at 8:24 PM, Tom Stephens wrote:
That document was an experiment by Microsoft to determine how well SSL and PCT could be merged into one protocol - using SSL as a base and adding PCT deltas.
>Most of all, if the working group is still working on an "actual spec," >what purpose is served by this unilateral STLP document?
Our goal was to deal with the differences Microsoft and Netscape quickly so that the normal IETF process would move forward without any detractions from either Microsoft or Netscape.
Our goal was to deal with the differences Microsoft and Netscape quickly so that the normal IETF process would move forward without any detractions from either Microsoft or Netscape.
Our goal was to deal with the differences Microsoft and Netscape quickly so that the normal IETF process would move forward without any detractions from either Microsoft or Netscape.
Our goal was to deal with the differences Microsoft and Netscape quickly so that the normal IETF process would move forward without any detractions from either Microsoft or Netscape.
Win Treese and representatives from Microsoft and Netscape met a couple of weeks ago to begin hammering out some of the components for the foundation of a spec.
To >>facilitate the discussion, you can find the STLP strawman document at: >> >>http://pct.microsoft.com/stlp.

To >>facilitate the discussion, you can find the STLP strawman document at: >> >>http://pct.microsoft.com/stlp.
That document was an experiment by Microsoft to determine how well SSL and PCT could be merged into one protocol - using SSL as a base and adding PCT deltas.
